articles.headline: Austin Beutner Ousted as Los Angeles Times Publisher
articles.snippet: Mr. Beutner’s dismissal as publisher and chief executive follows internal disagreement between the newspaper and its parent company, Tribune Publishing.
articles.abstract: Mr. Beutner’s dismissal as publisher and chief executive follows internal disagreement between the newspaper and its parent company, Tribune Publishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Austin Beutner, the publisher and chief executive of The Los Angeles Times, was dismissed on Tuesday after only a year in that position, the latest upheaval at a newspaper buffeted by management turmoil over the last decade.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton, Citing Her ‘Mistake,’ Apologizes for Private Email
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton said what many supporters had been wanting to hear in hopes that it would quell the controversy that has overshadowed her presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton said what many supporters had been wanting to hear in hopes that it would quell the controversy that has overshadowed her presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged on Tuesday that her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state was a “mistake,” and apologized directly for it, uttering words that many of her allies have waited to hear from her in hopes that she can quell a controversy that has dogged her presidential candidacy for months.

articles.headline: United C.E.O. Is Out Amid Inquiry at Port Authority
articles.snippet: The airline said two other executives were also leaving in connection with an investigation into whether flights were a favor for a top agency official.
articles.abstract: The airline said two other executives were also leaving in connection with an investigation into whether flights were a favor for a top agency official.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive and two senior officials of United Airlines resigned on Tuesday amid a federal investigation into whether the airline had traded favors with the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Corporate Efforts to Address Social Problems Have Limits
articles.snippet: A survey by researchers at Harvard Business School shows a recognition among executives of social problems, but pessimism that they can be addressed.
articles.abstract: A survey by researchers at Harvard Business School shows a recognition among executives of social problems, but pessimism that they can be addressed.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is something appealing about the concept of “shared value.”

articles.headline: Investment Strategies Meant as Buffers to Volatility May Have Deepened It
articles.snippet: Risk-parity and exchange-traded funds, both considered ways of providing steady returns in a pitching market, are now thought to have added to the turbulence.
articles.abstract: Risk-parity and exchange-traded funds, both considered ways of providing steady returns in a pitching market, are now thought to have added to the turbulence.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, a cure is proving to be nearly as bad as the disease.

articles.headline: China Flexes Tech Muscles Before a State Visit
articles.snippet: As President Xi Jinping prepared to visit the United States, Washington warned of possible sanctions over digital attacks. Beijing pushed back by organizing a technology forum of industry leaders.
articles.abstract: As President Xi Jinping prepared to visit the United States, Washington warned of possible sanctions over digital attacks. Beijing pushed back by organizing a technology forum of industry leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As President Xi Jinping of China prepares for his first state visit to the United States this month, Washington has warned that it could hit Chinese companies with sanctions over digital attacks for trade secrets. Beijing is now pushing back in an unorthodox way: by organizing a technology forum to demonstrate its own sway over the American tech industry.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Intel to End Sponsorship of Science Talent Search
articles.snippet: The high school competition counts among its past competitors eight Nobel Prize winners, along with chief executives, university professors and award-winning scientists.
articles.abstract: The high school competition counts among its past competitors eight Nobel Prize winners, along with chief executives, university professors and award-winning scientists.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, is dropping its longtime support of the most prestigious science and mathematics competition for American high school students.

articles.headline: E.U. Nations Urged to Accept 160,000 Migrants
articles.snippet: The president of the European Commission urged Europeans to remember ancestors who sought refuge from religious persecution and war and famine.
articles.abstract: The president of the European Commission urged Europeans to remember ancestors who sought refuge from religious persecution and war and famine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top executive proposed a plan on Wednesday to distribute 160,000 migrants throughout the member nations, even while acknowledging that this measure alone was inadequate to the depth of the crisis.

articles.headline: China’s Response to Stock Plunge Rattles Traders
articles.snippet: In addition to imposing extraordinary restrictions on the sale of stocks, the authorities have harnessed a security apparatus usually more focused on political dissent.
articles.abstract: In addition to imposing extraordinary restrictions on the sale of stocks, the authorities have harnessed a security apparatus usually more focused on political dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The police have been dropping in on investment firms and downloading their transaction records. Senior executives at China’s biggest investment bank have been arrested on suspicion of illegal trading. A business journalist has been detained and shown  apologizing on national television for writing an article that could have hurt the market.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Neil Gough and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Lays Out 5-Year Plan for Restructuring Its Debts
articles.snippet: The plan requires either concessions negotiated from creditors or legislation enacted in San Juan or Washington, suggesting a difficult road ahead.
articles.abstract: The plan requires either concessions negotiated from creditors or legislation enacted in San Juan or Washington, suggesting a difficult road ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to balance the demands of anxious island residents on one side and powerful financial institutions on the other, the governor of Puerto Rico announced a plan Wednesday for bailing the island out of debt that would require at least five years of bruising reform if it is to succeed.

articles.headline: National Geographic and Fox Form a Commercial Media Company
articles.snippet: The renowned National Geographic magazine will be included in the deal, though the society will retain its nonprofit status.
articles.abstract: The renowned National Geographic magazine will be included in the deal, though the society will retain its nonprofit status.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since 1888, the National Geographic Society has stood for science, discovery and storytelling. Its yellow-bordered magazine has served as the ultimate stage for award-winning photography, depicting the wonders of the world, and the group has supported pursuits as diverse as the underwater explorations of Jacques-Yves Cousteau and Jane Goodall’s study of chimpanzees in Tanzania.
